Article.ArticleTitle: Short-term effects of various ozone metrics on cardiopulmonary function in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease patients: Results from a panel study in Beijing, China.

AbstractText: Short-term exposure to ambient air pollution has been associated with lower pulmonary function and higher blood pressure (BP). However, controversy remains regarding the relationship between ambient multiple daily ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) metrics and cardiopulmonary health outcomes, especially in the developing countries.
To investigate and compare the short-term effects of various O<sub>3</sub> metrics on pulmonary function, fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) and BP in a panel study of COPD patients.

We measured pulmonary function, FeNO and BP repeatedly in a total of 43 patients with COPD for 215 home visits. Daily hourly ambient O<sub>3</sub> concentrations were obtained from central-monitoring stations close to subject residences. We calculated various O<sub>3</sub> metrics [daily 1-h maximum (O<sub>3</sub>-1 h max), maximum 8-h average (O<sub>3</sub>-8 h max) and 24-h average (O<sub>3</sub>-24 h avg)] based on the hourly data. Daily indoor O<sub>3</sub> concentrations were estimated based on estimated indoor/outdoor O<sub>3</sub> ratios. Linear mixed-effects models were used to estimate associations of various O<sub>3</sub> metrics with cardiopulmonary function variables.

An interquartile range (IQR) increase in ambient O<sub>3</sub>-8 h max (80.5 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, 5-d) was associated with a 5.9% (95%CI: -11.0%, -0.7%) reduction in forced expiratory volume in 1 s (FEV<sub>1</sub>) and a 6.2% (95%CI: -10.9%, -1.5%) reduction in peak expiratory flow (PEF). However, there were no significant negative associations between ambient O<sub>3</sub>-1 h max, O<sub>3</sub>-24 h avg and FEV<sub>1</sub>, PEF. An IQR increase in ambient O<sub>3</sub>-1 h max (85.3 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, 6-d) was associated with a 6.7 mmHg (95%CI: 0.7, 12.7) increase in systolic BP. The estimated indoor O<sub>3</sub> were still significantly associated with reduction of FEV<sub>1</sub> and PEF. No significant associations were found between various O<sub>3</sub> metrics and FeNO.

Our results provide clues for the adverse cardiopulmonary effects associated with various O<sub>3</sub> metrics in COPD patients and highlight that O<sub>3</sub>-8 h max was more closely associated with respiratory health variables.
